course.title: Seattle City Light – OT Cyber Security Incident Response (CSIR) Training
course.mission: Teach OT personnel how to recognize, report, and respond to cyber security incidents using the SCL OT CSIR Plan—clearly, safely, and consistently.
course.description: Role-based CSIR enablement with locked steps, role-aware guidance, and verifiable completion.

roles.label: All SCL Staff (OT, field, ops, engineering)
roles.whoItsFor: Anyone who touches OT environments or may observe/report suspicious activity.

roles.label: CSIR Team Member
roles.whoItsFor: Virtual response team participants supporting investigation, containment, and reporting.

roles.label: Incident Technical Lead
roles.whoItsFor: Leads technical investigation, containment, and recovery sequencing.

roles.label: Incident Commander
roles.whoItsFor: Supervisors/managers/directors coordinating the CSIR response and decisions.

roles.label: NERC-CIP Compliance Lead / Audit Support
roles.whoItsFor: Advisors on reportability, DOE-417 handling, evidence quality, and audit prep.

roles.label: Enterprise Cyber Security (ECS)
roles.whoItsFor: Detection, reporting, and governance teams who steward the CSIR plan.

contentBlocks.text: **What you’ll learn**

items: Recognize cyber events vs incidents
Know what to do first and who to contact
Understand severity levels and escalation
Follow the CSIR phases (Preparation through Follow-up)
Handle audits professionally (what to say / not say)

contentBlocks.title: Estimated time
contentBlocks.text: Time adjusts by role path. Steps unlock in order. Use "Start training" to continue.

contentBlocks.title: Optional CIP alignment
contentBlocks.text: Need CIP-007 alignment? Open the Appendix at modules/cip007/index.html after you finish the core CSIR steps.
In OT, cyber incidents aren’t just IT problems—they can affect monitoring, control, and safe operation.
Your priority order: **Safe → Secure → Reliable operations**.

contentBlocks.title: If safety conflicts with security
contentBlocks.text: Escalate immediately to the Asset Owner or incident leadership for direction.

questions.prompt: What is always the top priority?
What do you do if security steps conflict with operations?
options: Pause and escalate to the Asset Owner/incident leadership

steps.title: Definitions: Event vs Incident vs Attempt to Compromise

contentBlocks.text: **Cyber Event:** unusual activity that could impact cyber assets (can be benign like misconfigurations).
**Cyber Security Incident:** malicious or suspicious act that compromises or attempts to compromise a cyber asset.
**Attempt to Compromise (AtC):** suspicious activity involving protected systems where compromise did not occur (still reportable depending on scope).

contentBlocks.title: Reportable Cyber Security Incident
contentBlocks.text: Defined by mandatory reporting criteria; reporting obligations apply when determined reportable.

interaction.prompt: Classify each scenario as Event, Incident, or Attempt to Compromise (AtC).

items.text: Unexpected reboot after patch window
items.why: Post-maintenance instability is abnormal but not clearly malicious.

items.text: Multiple failed logins from unknown source to OT jump host
items.why: Brute-force behavior on a protected entry point.

items.text: Port scan detected against protected perimeter
items.why: Recon against protected systems without confirmed compromise.

items.text: Technician reports badge door forced open near OT cabinet
items.why: Physical tampering with potential malicious intent; escalate if uncertain.

items.text: Malware alert on engineering workstation
items.why: Confirmed malicious indicator on an OT asset.

items.text: Misconfiguration breaks polling to historian
items.why: Operational impact without malicious intent yet.

items.text: Default account login attempt repeatedly fails
items.why: Suspicious attempt to authenticate with weak credentials.

items.text: Unauthorized new account created on OT admin system

contentBlocks.text: Use the severity ladder to guide escalation and communications.

items: Critical: cannot provide critical services; significant interruption to power system operations
High: moderate interruption or major business continuity risk; broad impact likely
Medium: suspected/actual activity could impact reliability or critical systems; precursor to focused attack
Low: minimal effect; suspicious activity / recon; efficiency loss

interaction.prompt: Match each scenario to a likely severity.

items.text: Control center cannot dispatch commands due to malware
Engineering workstation infected; polling degraded but still operating
Reconnaissance scan on OT firewall
Ransom note on asset owner laptop with OT engineering tools
Unauthorized remote access attempt blocked by MFA
Loss of monitoring for multiple substations

contentBlocks.text: The CSIR plan moves through six phases. Click each phase to see what it means for you.

items.title: Preparation
items.text: Keep plan and materials current; ensure monitoring/logging; backups and images ready; know reporting mechanisms.

items.title: Identification
items.text: Recognize signals; classify quickly; assign ownership; determine affected systems and people.

items.title: Investigation
items.text: Confirm classification/severity; determine scope; expand notification as needed.

items.title: Response
items.text: Contain, eradicate, and recover; ensure required reporting occurs.

items.title: Recovery
items.text: Restore normal ops, validate systems, and prevent recurrence.

items.title: Follow Up
items.text: Capture lessons learned; update documentation; continue monitoring.

contentBlocks.title: Role callouts
contentBlocks.text: Each phase shows "What YOU do" based on your role selection inside the runner.

interaction.prompt: Open your role plus at least one other role to see responsibilities and evidence.

items.title: All SCL Staff
responsible: Recognize and report suspicious activity immediately

contentBlocks.text: Communications are coordinated by incident leadership (usually the Incident Commander). Avoid freelancing.

contentBlocks.title: Media requests
contentBlocks.text: Route all media questions to authorized channels; do not speculate.

questions.prompt: What do you do if asked by media?

contentBlocks.text: Two key deadlines: reportable incident within **1 hour** of determining reportable; Attempt to Compromise by **end of next business day** after determination.

items: Where reports go: E-ISAC (email + phone), CISA Central (email + phone), SOC email distribution.
Minimum info: functional impact, attack vector, level of intrusion achieved/attempted.
Forms and storage: DOE-417 plus internal storage for backups/logs.

contentBlocks.title: Role gating
contentBlocks.text: All staff need awareness; CSIR reporters/ECS/Compliance review the detailed checklist below.

questions.prompt: When must a reportable cyber security incident be submitted?

options: By end of next business day after determination
Functional impact, attack vector, intrusion level
Secure internal repository aligned to ECS

contentBlocks.text: Document what you saw, when, what systems, who you told, and what actions were taken.
Preserve evidence integrity: avoid modifying or overwriting logs; prefer isolation over power-off when safe.

contentBlocks.title: Incident log essentials
contentBlocks.text: Include incident number, discovery time, event time, systems affected, actions taken, and who approved them.

items: I will capture what I saw, when, and on which system.
I will avoid modifying or deleting potential evidence.
If safe, I will isolate rather than power off to preserve state.
I will record who I notified and when.
I will note any containment or recovery actions taken.

contentBlocks.text: Containment is a first goal after evidence gathering. Remove avenues of compromise, isolate affected systems, and preserve evidence.

contentBlocks.title: Coordinate
contentBlocks.text: Coordinate with the Technical Lead and Incident Commander. Always prioritize safe operations.
Work through realistic OT scenarios.

items: **Relay mis-operates after config change**: First action is to stabilize operations and notify Technical Lead; you are in Identification moving toward Investigation; likely Medium to High depending on impact; notify Asset Owner, ICS lead, and ECS because of potential reliability risk.

**Substation HMI shows ransomware note**: Prioritize safety; isolate affected HMI from network if safe; you are in Response; severity High or Critical depending on impact; notify Incident Commander, Technical Lead, ECS, and Operations leadership immediately.
**OT firewall shows repeated blocked outbound traffic from engineering host**: Begin Investigation; likely Medium; notify Technical Lead/ECS; capture logs before containment.

**Badge anomalies near critical cabinets with simultaneous failed logins**: Treat as coordinated Incident; severity High; escalate to Incident Commander and Compliance Lead for potential reportability.
Answer only what is asked; keep it factual and brief.
If you do not know: say so and offer to verify and follow up.
Use evidence and documented procedures; avoid opinions or guesses.
Do not invent timelines, causes, or remediation steps.
Ask for clarification if a question is ambiguous or out of scope.
Confirm the exact artifact requested (log, ticket, screenshot, report).
Identify the system time, time zone, and any clock offsets used in evidence.

contentBlocks.title: Audit do and do not
contentBlocks.text: Do: cite the CSIR plan, incident logs, and approved runbooks. Do not: speculate, share drafts, or expose sensitive data outside approved channels.

contentBlocks.title: If asked outside your scope
contentBlocks.text: State your role, explain what you observed, and direct the auditor to the Incident Commander, ECS, or Compliance lead for final responses.

options: Say you will verify and follow up

questions.prompt: Should you create timelines you don’t recall?

contentBlocks.title: Downloadable operational checklist
contentBlocks.text: Prevent, Detect, and Respond groupings with review frequency guidance.

items: Prevent: keep backups/images current, maintain monitoring/logging on critical systems, update contact lists monthly.
Detect: recognize anomalies, verify maintenance windows, escalate suspicious indicators promptly.
Respond: report quickly, preserve evidence, follow leadership direction, document actions.
